# Na Pr√°tica: Manipulando Dados

--

* Voc√™ gastar√° muito tempo preparando dados para an√°lise posterior.

--

* O conjunto de dados `gapminder` cont√©m dados sobre expectativa de vida, PIB per capita e popula√ß√£o por pa√≠s entre 1952 e 2007.

* Suponha que queremos saber a expectativa m√©dia de vida e o PIB m√©dio per capita para cada continente em cada ano.

--

* Precisamos agrupar os dados por continente *e* ano e, em seguida, calcular a expectativa m√©dia de vida e o PIB m√©dio per capita
--

.pull-left[
```{r, gapminder, echo = T, eval = F}
# load gapminder package
library(gapminder)
# load the dataset from the gapminder package
data(gapminder, package = "gapminder") 
# display variables in the dataset
names(gapminder)
# show first 4 lines of this dataframe
head(gapminder,n = 4)
```
]

.pull-right[
```{r, gapminder, echo = F, eval = T}
```
]

---

# Na Pr√°tica: Manipulando Dados

* H√° sempre v√°rias maneiras de atingir um objetivo. (Como na vida `r emo::ji("smile")`)

* Aqui vamos focar apenas no jeito `tidyverse`:

```{r}
# compute the required statistics
gapminder_dplyr <- gapminder %>% 
  group_by(continent, year) %>% 
  summarise(count = n(),
            mean_lifeexp = mean(lifeExp),
            mean_gdppercap = mean(gdpPercap))
```

```{r}
# show first 5 lines of the new data
head(gapminder_dplyr, n = 5)
```

---

# Visualiza√ß√£o

.pull-left[
* Agora podemos *olhar* o resultado em `gapminder_dplyr`, ou calcular algumas estat√≠sticas a partir dele.

* Nada supera uma figura, no entanto:

```{r gampminder_plot, eval = FALSE}
ggplot(data = gapminder_dplyr, 
       mapping = aes(x = mean_lifeexp,
                     y = mean_gdppercap,
                     color = continent,
                     size = count)) +
  geom_point(alpha = 1/3) +
  labs(x = "Expectativa de vida m√©dia",
       y = "PIB per capita m√©dio",
       color = "Continente",
       size = "N√∫m. de pa√≠ses")
```
]

.pull-right[
```{r gampminder_plot, echo = FALSE}
```
]

* [`RStudio`](https://www.rstudio.com/): √© um ambiente integrado de desenvolvimento (IDE) para se trabalhar com o `R`.

* *comando*: entrada do usu√°rio (texto ou n√∫meros) que o `R` *entende*.

* *script*: uma lista de comandos colados em um arquivo de texto, cada um separado por uma nova linha, para serem executados um ap√≥s o outro.

# R Packages

* `R` users contribute add-on data and functions as *packages*

* Installing packages is easy! Just use the `install.packages` function:
    ```{r, eval = FALSE}
    install.packages("ggplot2") # do NOT run this code on your end
    ```

* To *use* the contents of a packge, we must load it from our library using `library`:
    ```{r, message = FALSE, warning = FALSE,eval=FALSE}
    library(ggplot2)
    ```

---

# Vectors

* The `c` function creates vectors, i.e. an array of elements.
    ```{r}
    c(1, 3, 5, 7, 8, 9)
    ```
    
--

* Coercion to unique types:
    ```{r}
    c(42, "Statistics", TRUE)
    ```

--

* Creating a *range*
    ```{r}
    1:10
    ```

---

# `data.frame`'s

`data.frame`s are like spreadsheets.

```{r}
example_data = data.frame(x = c(1, 3, 5, 7),
                          y = c(rep("Hello", 3), "Goodbye"),
                          z = c("one", 2, "three", 4))
example_data
```

In practice, you will be importing files that contain the data into `R` rather than creating `data.frame`s by hand.

# `data.frame`s

Useful functions to describe a dataframe:
```{r}
str(murders) # describes the data.frame
```

--

```{r}
names(murders) # column names
```

--

```{r}
nrow(murders) # number of rows
```

--

```{r}
ncol(murders) # number of columns
```

---

# Data on Gun Murders in the US
    
* To access one of the variables **as a vector** we use the `$` operator as in `murders$state`.
    ```{r}
    murders$state
    ```

--

.pull-left[
* We can check the type of `murders$state` with
    ```{r}
    class(murders$state)
    ```
]

--

.pull-right[
* Or we use the column name or index: `murders[,"state"]` or `murders[,1]`
    ```{r}
    class(murders[,"state"])
    ```
]

---

# Subsetting `data.frames`

* Subsetting a data.frame: `murders[row condition, column number]` or `murders[row condition, "column name"]`
    ```{r}
    # Only keep states with over 500 gun murders and keep only the "state" and "total" variables
    murders[murders$total > 500, c("state", "total")]
    
    # Only keep California and Texas and keep only the "state" and "total" variables
    murders[murders$state %in% c("California", "Texas"), c("state", "total")]
    ```

---

# Task 3


1. How many observations are there in `murders`?

1. How many variables? What are the data types of each variable?

1. Create a new object `murders_3` which only contains the columns `state` and `total`. (Recall that `c` creates vectors.)

1. Create a `total_percap` variable equal to the number of murders per 10,000 inhabitants by running the following code.

    murders$total_percap = (murders$total / murders$population) * 10000
